matcher.options: Idle - Waiting for something to happen

targets.legendFormat: System - Processes executing in kernel mode
User - Normal processes executing in user mode
Nice - Niced processes executing in user mode
Idle - Waiting for something to happen
Iowait - Waiting for I/O to complete
Steal - Time spent in other operating systems when running in a virtualized environment
Guest - Time spent running a virtual CPU for a guest operating system

matcher.options: Hardware Corrupted - Amount of RAM that the kernel identified as corrupted / not working

targets.legendFormat: Apps - Memory used by user-space applications
PageTables - Memory used to map between virtual and physical memory addresses
SwapCache - Memory that keeps track of pages that have been fetched from swap but not yet been modified
Slab - Memory used by the kernel to cache data structures for its own use (caches like inode, dentry, etc)
Cache - Parked file data (file content) cache
Hardware Corrupted - Amount of RAM that the kernel identified as corrupted / not working

matcher.options: Hardware Corrupted - Amount of RAM that the kernel identified as corrupted / not working

targets.legendFormat: Inactive - Memory which has been less recently used.  It is more eligible to be reclaimed for other purposes
Active - Memory that has been used more recently and usually not reclaimed unless absolutely necessary

matcher.options: Hardware Corrupted - Amount of RAM that the kernel identified as corrupted / not working

targets.legendFormat: Committed_AS - Amount of memory presently allocated on the system
CommitLimit - Amount of  memory currently available to be allocated on the system

matcher.options: Hardware Corrupted - Amount of RAM that the kernel identified as corrupted / not working

targets.legendFormat: Inactive_file - File-backed memory on inactive LRU list
Inactive_anon - Anonymous and swap cache on inactive LRU list, including tmpfs (shmem)
Active_file - File-backed memory on active LRU list
Active_anon - Anonymous and swap cache on active least-recently-used (LRU) list, including tmpfs
Writeback - Memory which is actively being written back to disk
WritebackTmp - Memory used by FUSE for temporary writeback buffers
Dirty - Memory which is waiting to get written back to the disk

matcher.options: Hardware Corrupted - Amount of RAM that the kernel identified as corrupted / not working
ShmemHugePages - Memory used by shared memory (shmem) and tmpfs allocated  with huge pages
ShmemHugePages - Memory used by shared memory (shmem) and tmpfs allocated  with huge pages

targets.legendFormat: Mapped - Used memory in mapped pages files which have been mmaped, such as libraries
Shmem - Used shared memory (shared between several processes, thus including RAM disks)
ShmemHugePages - Memory used by shared memory (shmem) and tmpfs allocated  with huge pages
ShmemPmdMapped - Ammount of shared (shmem/tmpfs) memory backed by huge pages
SUnreclaim - Part of Slab, that cannot be reclaimed on memory pressure
SReclaimable - Part of Slab, that might be reclaimed, such as caches
VmallocChunk - Largest contigious block of vmalloc area which is free
VmallocTotal - Total size of vmalloc memory area
VmallocUsed - Amount of vmalloc area which is used

matcher.options: Hardware Corrupted - Amount of RAM that the kernel identified as corrupted / not working

targets.legendFormat: Bounce - Memory used for block device bounce buffers
AnonHugePages - Memory in anonymous huge pages
AnonPages - Memory in user pages not backed by files

matcher.options: Hardware Corrupted - Amount of RAM that the kernel identified as corrupted / not working

targets.legendFormat: KernelStack - Kernel memory stack. This is not reclaimable
PerCPU - Per CPU memory allocated dynamically by loadable modules
HugePages_Free - Huge pages in the pool that are not yet allocated
HugePages_Rsvd - Huge pages for which a commitment to allocate from the pool has been made, but no allocation has yet been made
HugePages_Surp - Huge pages in the pool above the value in /proc/sys/vm/nr_hugepages
HugePages - Total size of the pool of huge pages
DirectMap1G - Amount of pages mapped as this size
DirectMap2M - Amount of pages mapped as this size
DirectMap4K - Amount of pages mapped as this size

matcher.options: Hardware Corrupted - Amount of RAM that the kernel identified as corrupted / not working

targets.legendFormat: Unevictable - Amount of unevictable memory that can't be swapped out for a variety of reasons
MLocked - Size of pages locked to memory using the mlock() system call
NFS Unstable - Memory in NFS pages sent to the server, but not yet commited to the storage

matcher.options: Hardware Corrupted - Amount of RAM that the kernel identified as corrupted / not working
Pgfault - Page major and minor fault operations

targets.legendFormat: Pgfault - Page major and minor fault operations
Time offset in between local system and reference clock
Is clock synchronized to a reliable server (1 = yes, 0 = no)
Processes blocked waiting for I/O to complete
Processes virtual memory size in bytes
Maximum amount of virtual memory available in bytes
Processes virtual memory size in bytes
Maximum amount of virtual memory available in bytes
Entropy available to random number generators

panels.title: CPU time spent in user and system contexts

panels.description: The number (after merges) of I/O requests completed per second for the device
panels.title: Disk IOps Completed

panels.description: The number of bytes read from or written to the device per second
panels.title: Disk R/W Data

panels.description: The average time for requests issued to the device to be served. This includes the time spent by the requests in queue and the time spent servicing them.
panels.title: Disk Average Wait Time

panels.description: The average queue length of the requests that were issued to the device
panels.title: Average Queue Size

panels.description: The number of read and write requests merged per second that were queued to the device
panels.title: Disk R/W Merged

panels.description: Percentage of elapsed time during which I/O requests were issued to the device (bandwidth utilization for the device). Device saturation occurs when this value is close to 100% for devices serving requests serially.  But for devices  serving requests in parallel, such as RAID arrays and modern SSDs, this number does not reflect their performance limits.
panels.title: Time Spent Doing I/Os

panels.description: The number of outstanding requests at the instant the sample was taken. Incremented as requests are given to appropriate struct request_queue and decremented as they finish.
panels.title: Instantaneous Queue Size

targets.legendFormat: TCP_inuse - Tcp sockets currently in use
UDPLITE_inuse - Udplite sockets currently in use
UDP_inuse - Udp sockets currently in use
mem_bytes - TCP sockets in that state
mem_bytes - UDP sockets in that state
FRAG_inuse - Frag sockets currently in use
RAW_inuse - Raw sockets currently in use
InMsgs -  Messages which the entity received. Note that this counter includes all those counted by icmpInErrors
OutMsgs - Messages which this entity attempted to send. Note that this counter includes all those counted by icmpOutErrors
InErrors - Messages which the entity received but determined as having ICMP-specific errors (bad ICMP checksums, bad length, etc.)
InErrors - UDP Datagrams that could not be delivered to an application
NoPorts - UDP Datagrams received on a port with no listener
InErrors Lite - UDPLite Datagrams that could not be delivered to an application
InSegs - Segments received, including those received in error. This count includes segments received on currently established connections
OutSegs - Segments sent, including those on current connections but excluding those containing only retransmitted octets
ListenOverflows - Times the listen queue of a socket overflowed
ListenDrops - SYNs to LISTEN sockets ignored
TCPSynRetrans - SYN-SYN/ACK retransmits to break down retransmissions in SYN, fast/timeout retransmits
RetransSegs - Segments retransmitted - that is, the number of TCP segments transmitted containing one or more previously transmitted octets
InErrs - Segments received in error (e.g., bad TCP checksums)
CurrEstab - TCP connections for which the current state is either ESTABLISHED or CLOSE- WAIT
MaxConn - Limit on the total number of TCP connections the entity can support (Dinamic is "-1")
ActiveOpens - TCP connections that have made a direct transition to the SYN-SENT state from the CLOSED state
PassiveOpens - TCP connections that have made a direct transition to the SYN-RCVD state from the LISTEN state
TW - TCP sockets finished time wait in fast timer
TWKilled - TCP sockets finished time wait in slow timer
TWRecycled - Time wait sockets recycled by time stamp
TCPTimeWaitOverflow - Occurences of time wait bucket overflow
